title: Lecture 07.12.2025
transcript: vSE 380 – Mobile Application Development Lecture 2: Declarative UI Lecturer: Gazihan Alankuş All rights reserved, cannot be used in any educational institution other than Izmir University of Economics. Please look at the couple of slides for assignments (marked with TODO) A problem: source of information Declarative Programming • In • Flutter • React/React Native • Jetpack Compose (Android) • Swift UI (iOS) we create the user interface in a style called “declarative programming”. • The kind of programming that most of you are used to is called “imperative programming”. • Android SDK • iOS SDK • What is the difference? What exactly are they? A computer program vs. an electronic circuit Imperative vs. Declarative Imperative Declarative • Giving orders in detail, with explicit instructions • Describing how it should be • Do this, then do that, then do this other thing. • Programmer has full control. • Programmer has full responsibility. • The computer is dumb. • Here is how I would like it to look like. I don’t have control over how exactly you are doing it. • Programmer has limited control. • Programmer has limited responsibility. • The computer is smart. Imperative vs. Declarative Imperative Declarative • Java • C++ • Step-by-step programming • HTML • SQL • Designing a circuit-like system • Procedural languages • Functional languages Is it just the language? • No, it’s the style. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mt7KnvnNGfk How are React Native and Flutter Declarative? • JavaScript and Dart are procedural languages. Shouldn’t it be imperative? • Answer: there are imperative parts of your code. The code that generates the UI is declarative. Declarative code from React Native and Flutter. Declarative code from React Native and Flutter. • Although the language is suitable for imperative code, the framework forces declarative code. • You create and tie UI elements together. • You do not modify or manage existing UI elements. • There is no such code in either: • txtField.text = “new text” • pnlMain.addChild(txtField) • Instead, there is such code: • new Panel(new TextField(“hello”)); UI Code • React Native • JSX • (short for JavaScript XML) • Similar to HTML • The description for the UI. Creates the UI. • Not actual code • Limited customization • No debugging • Flutter • Widget constructors • Named parameters • child for single child • children for multiple • Actual code! • Fully customizable • Fully debuggable UI is a tree • The UI is a tree structure • Creating a tree is easy • Modifying and maintaining a tree is difficult • This is why they chose declarative • We create and re-create UI elements. We do not manage existing elements. • What? How? • How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a button? Imperative Example • How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a button? Panel panel = new Panel(); TextField t = new TextField(); panel.add(t); t.text = “one”; Button b = new Button(); panel.add(b); b.addClickHandler(() { t.text = “two”; }); • THIS IS IMPERATIVE CODE. THIS MAKES SENSE. • This is not how React Native or Flutter do it. Declarative Example • How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a button? String currentValue = “one”; buildUi() { new Panel( new Text(currentValue), new Button( onClick: () { currentValue = “two”; rebuildUi(); } ) ) } • THIS IS DECLARATIVE CODE. THIS IS COUNTER-INTUITIVE • Why does React Native and Flutter use this pattern? Compare them. Panel panel = new Panel(); TextField t = new TextField(); panel.add(t); t.text = “one”; Button b = new Button(); panel.add(b); b.addClickHandler(() { String currentValue = “one”; buildUi() { new Panel( new Text(currentValue), new Button( onClick: () { currentValue = “two”; rebuildUi(); } ) t.text = “two”; }); ) } The difference • Imperative • Declarative • You create elements • You attach them together • You create elements • You attach them together • You keep a reference to elements • You do not keep a reference to elements • You are not responsible for maintaining elements • You do not give them orders • You create them and forget about them • You are responsible for mainaining them • You give them orders • You recreate them when something changes How can you keep recreating the UI? • Isn’t it inefficient? How can you keep recreating the UI? • Isn’t it inefficient? • NO! People smarter than us have implemented it carefully. • What you are creating is not the real UI element. It’s just a light description of them. • Very light data structure, system is ok with creating and destroying them quickly. • The framework finds the difference between two versions of the tree and modifies the UI elements whose description actually changed. • Carefully crafted framework to give you the ability to “just recreate the UI”. • DO NOT TRY TO OPTIMIZE ANYTHING ABOUT IT!!! • DO NOT CACHE UI ELEMENTS, ETC. KEEP RECREATING THEM. Planning and Creating a Declarative UI • How should you go about planning your UI? • https://reactjs.org/docs/thinking-in-react.html •FilterableProductTable • SearchBar • ProductTable • ProductCategoryRow • ProductRow How does data flow? https://livebook.manning.com/book/react-in-action/chapter-3/112 How does data flow? https://www.slideshare.net/pheadra4/react-46872849?from_action=save How does data flow? https://www.slideshare.net/pheadra4/react-46872849?from_action=save How does data flow? • Unidirectional data flow • Top to bottom • Props/constructor arguments (fixed) • Data being passed down when component is created (yellow). • State (changing) • Temporary data that changes with user input or other events • Triggers a rebuild of subtree. Data is passed down as new version of props. • Bottom to top • Events • Lower level component communicates up https://tkssharma.gitbook.io/react-training/day-01/react-js-3-principles/one-way-data-flow How does data flow? • Unidirectional data flow • Top to bottom • Props/constructor arguments (fixed) • Data being passed down when component is created (yellow). • State (changing) • Temporary data that changes with user input or other events • Triggers a rebuild of subtree. Data is passed down as new version of props. • Bottom to top • Events • Lower level component communicates up https://tkssharma.gitbook.io/react-training/day-01/react-js-3-principles/one-way-data-flow Other approaches • Passing data around can be cumbersome • All intermediate levels need to know about the data being passed to a leaf • Solution: state management • Redux • MobX • Provider • Etc. • WARNING: Learn the basics well before starting these approaches! • Try it with setState first. Write a couple of apps with it first. After you really feel the need, start learning about a state management approach. modules.title: Module 1: Foundations of UI Programming Paradigms
modules.goal: Distinguish between imperative and declarative programming and understand their implications for UI development.

lessons.title: Lesson 1.1: Imperative vs. Declarative: The Core Difference
lessons.objective: Define and differentiate imperative and declarative programming with examples relevant to UI.

activities.prompt: Review 'Imperative vs. Declarative' slides and transcript sections, focusing on definitions and examples like Java/C++ vs. HTML/SQL.
activities.expected_outcome: Ability to explain the core differences in programming style.

activities.prompt: Watch the recommended YouTube video on imperative vs. declarative programming styles (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mt7KnvnNGfk).
activities.expected_outcome: Deeper understanding of the conceptual shift.

activities.prompt: Brainstorm 2-3 real-world analogies for imperative and declarative instructions (e.g., cooking recipes vs. ordering from a menu).
activities.expected_outcome: Reinforced understanding through analogy.

mini_quiz: What is the primary characteristic of imperative programming?
How does declarative programming typically handle 'control' and 'responsibility' compared to imperative?
Name two programming languages or technologies that align with declarative style, as mentioned in the lecture.

lessons.title: Lesson 1.2: The Problem with Traditional UI & The UI Tree
lessons.objective: Identify common problems in imperative UI development (e.g., source of information, spaghetti code) and understand why UI naturally forms a tree structure.

activities.prompt: Read the lecture sections discussing 'A problem: source of information' and 'UI is a tree'.
activities.expected_outcome: Identification of pain points in imperative UI and the inherent structure of UIs.

activities.prompt: Re-listen to the lecturer's explanation of the '200 messages' example and the visual drawing of a UI tree.
activities.expected_outcome: Clear understanding of how UI problems manifest and the tree analogy.

activities.prompt: Sketch a simple mobile app screen (e.g., a login screen) and break it down into a hierarchical tree structure of UI elements.
activities.expected_outcome: Application of UI tree concept to a practical example.

mini_quiz: Describe the 'source of information' problem in UI development as explained by the lecturer.
Why is a UI typically described as a 'tree structure'?
What kind of issues arise when human developers try to 'maintain trees' in an imperative way?

modules.title: Module 2: Building Declarative UIs
modules.goal: Comprehend the mechanisms and principles behind building modern declarative user interfaces using frameworks like Flutter and React Native.

lessons.title: Lesson 2.1: Declarative UI Frameworks: How They Work
lessons.objective: Explain how frameworks like Flutter and React Native enable declarative UI despite using imperative languages, focusing on UI re-creation.

activities.prompt: Review slides and transcript sections explaining 'How are React Native and Flutter Declarative?' and 'How can you keep recreating the UI?'.
activities.expected_outcome: Understanding of framework's role in abstracting UI management.

activities.prompt: Focus on the code examples for imperative vs. declarative UI to understand the syntax difference (e.g., `txtField.text = "new text"` vs. `new Panel(new TextField("hello"))`).
activities.expected_outcome: Ability to distinguish declarative code patterns.

activities.prompt: Summarize in your own words why recreating the UI on every state change is not inefficient in declarative frameworks.
activities.expected_outcome: Articulate the underlying optimization mechanism.

mini_quiz: How do declarative UI frameworks handle UI updates (e.g., when a text field changes)?
What is the key difference in how you interact with UI elements in imperative vs. declarative code?
Why should developers 'DO NOT TRY TO OPTIMIZE' UI re-creation in declarative frameworks?

lessons.title: Lesson 2.2: Data Flow in Declarative UIs (Props & State)
lessons.objective: Understand the unidirectional data flow model, differentiating between 'props' (or constructor arguments) and 'state' as sources of UI data.

activities.prompt: Study the 'How does data flow?' slides and transcript sections, paying close attention to 'Props/constructor arguments' and 'State'.
activities.expected_outcome: Clear distinction between fixed and changing data sources in UI components.

activities.prompt: Review the provided external links on unidirectional data flow (e.g., Manning, Slideshare, Gitbook) for alternative explanations and diagrams.
activities.expected_outcome: Comprehensive grasp of data flow principles.

activities.prompt: Given a simple UI component (e.g., a button displaying a count), identify which parts would be 'props' and which would be 'state' if it were built declaratively.
activities.expected_outcome: Practical application of props and state concepts.

mini_quiz: What is 'unidirectional data flow' and why is it important in declarative UIs?
Differentiate between 'props' (or constructor arguments) and 'state' in a declarative UI context.
What triggers a 'rebuild of subtree' in a declarative UI when data changes?

modules.title: Module 3: Practical Application & Best Practices
modules.goal: Apply declarative UI concepts to practical development scenarios and understand best practices for state management and development workflow.

lessons.title: Lesson 3.1: Planning Declarative UIs and Advanced State Management
lessons.objective: Identify strategies for planning declarative UIs and understand the role and caveats of advanced state management solutions.

activities.prompt: Read the sections on 'Planning and Creating a Declarative UI' (referencing 'Thinking in React') and 'Other approaches' to data flow.
activities.expected_outcome: Awareness of UI planning methodologies and advanced state management techniques.

activities.prompt: Based on the 'Thinking in React' example, outline how you would break down a complex UI into smaller, manageable declarative components.
activities.expected_outcome: Ability to apply component-based thinking to UI design.

activities.prompt: Reflect on the lecturer's warning about advanced state management. Why is it crucial to 'learn the basics well' first?
activities.expected_outcome: Understanding of the importance of foundational knowledge before adopting complex tools.

mini_quiz: What is the recommended approach for planning a declarative UI, as suggested by the 'Thinking in React' model?
Name two advanced state management solutions mentioned in the lecture.
What is the lecturer's key warning regarding advanced state management solutions?

lessons.title: Lesson 3.2: Enhancing Developer Experience with Declarative Frameworks
lessons.objective: Appreciate the 'developer luxuries' and efficient workflows offered by modern declarative UI frameworks.

activities.prompt: Re-listen to the lecturer's introduction, focusing on the discussion about Flutter's 'luxuries' like hot reload and UI inspection.
activities.expected_outcome: Understanding of how modern tools improve developer productivity and satisfaction.

activities.prompt: Consider your own past experiences with UI development (if any). How would features like hot reload and UI inspectors have improved your workflow?
activities.expected_outcome: Relating lecture content to personal experience.

mini_quiz: Describe two 'luxuries' of Flutter that enhance the developer experience.
How does 'preserving the current state' during code changes (hot reload) contribute to a better development workflow?
Why is a good 'developer experience' considered valuable in modern mobile application development?

emphases.statement: Declarative programming is a fundamental shift from imperative programming, where you describe *what* the UI should look like rather than *how* to build or update it.
emphases.why: This is the core conceptual understanding required for modern mobile UI development. Misunderstanding this leads to incorrect development patterns and difficulty in grasping framework concepts. Essential for exam questions on programming paradigms.
emphases.evidence: The lecturer provides repeated explanations, multiple comparison slides, and uses analogies (e.g., electronic circuit vs. computer program) to highlight this core distinction. He explicitly states his intention to dive deep into 'what declarative UI means'.
emphases.from_transcript_quote: declarative means declare, I'm declaring it to you, I'm describing it to you, I'm saying, oh, it is ahead, it has a body, two arms and two legs, so I'm describing something, okay? That's the idea, you are programming in a way you are describing things, okay?
emphases.from_slide_quote: Imperative: Giving orders in detail, with explicit instructions. Declarative: Describing how it should be.

emphases.statement: Declarative UI frameworks (like Flutter, React Native) abstract away complex UI management by making the developer re-create the UI description on every state change, and the framework efficiently determines actual UI updates.
emphases.why: This explains *how* declarative UI works in practice and addresses a common developer intuition about inefficiency. Understanding this mechanism is crucial for using these frameworks correctly and avoiding anti-patterns, which is vital for performance and maintainability.
emphases.evidence: The lecturer dedicates significant time to explain that UI elements are recreated, not modified, and explicitly warns, 'DO NOT TRY TO OPTIMIZE ANYTHING ABOUT IT!!! DO NOT CACHE UI ELEMENTS, ETC. KEEP RECREATING THEM.' The slides also directly address the 'inefficiency' concern.
emphases.from_transcript_quote: We create and re-create UI elements. We do not manage existing elements... NO! People smarter than us have implemented it carefully. What you are creating is not the real UI element. It’s just a light description of them.
emphases.from_slide_quote: The framework finds the difference between two versions of the tree and modifies the UI elements whose description actually changed.

emphases.statement: The 'source of information' problem and the inherent tree structure of UIs are core difficulties in imperative UI development that declarative programming aims to solve.
emphases.why: This highlights the primary motivation and advantages of the declarative approach, providing essential context for *why* this paradigm shift occurred. Understanding the problems (e.g., spaghetti code, difficulty with tree traversal) helps appreciate the solution and its design principles.
emphases.evidence: The lecture explicitly frames 'A problem: source of information' at the beginning and elaborates on how it leads to 'spaghetti code'. Both the LEC and SLIDE introduce the UI as a tree and discuss the difficulty humans have with 'maintaining trees' in imperative contexts.
emphases.from_transcript_quote: So a problem in UI software is source of information. Where is the data coming from? Which data am I supposed to show it on the screen right now? ... it can become a spaghetti code very quickly.
emphases.from_slide_quote: UI is a tree. Modifying and maintaining a tree is difficult. This is why they chose declarative.

emphases.statement: Unidirectional data flow, managed through 'props' (fixed data passed down) and 'state' (changing data causing rebuilds), is a fundamental principle for organizing data in declarative UIs.
emphases.why: This is a critical practical concept for designing and implementing interactive declarative UIs. Students must understand how data moves between components and triggers updates, which is central to building responsive applications.
emphases.evidence: There is a dedicated section titled 'How does data flow?' with multiple supporting slides and detailed explanations in the transcript about data flowing 'Top to bottom (Props/constructor arguments, State)' and 'Bottom to top (Events)'.
emphases.from_transcript_quote: Unidirectional data flow. Top to bottom. Props/constructor arguments (fixed)... State (changing) Temporary data that changes with user input or other events. Triggers a rebuild of subtree.
emphases.from_slide_quote: Unidirectional data flow. Top to bottom: Props/constructor arguments (fixed), State (changing). Bottom to top: Events.

emphases.statement: Modern declarative UI frameworks like Flutter offer significant 'developer luxuries' such as hot reload and UI inspection tools, drastically improving development speed and experience.
emphases.why: Although not a core conceptual paradigm, the lecturer emphasizes these practical benefits extensively at the beginning of the lecture. Understanding these features highlights the appeal and efficiency gains of using modern declarative frameworks for mobile development.
emphases.evidence: The lecturer spends a good portion of the introductory segment discussing 'two luxuries of Flutter,' using a detailed intern story to illustrate the immense value of preserving state with hot reload and the UI inspection feature. The slide mentions Declarative UI as the 'third luxury' but doesn't detail the others.
emphases.from_transcript_quote: Another luxury was I edited some code, saved it and immediately like less than a second usually later I saw it, I saw my running app change to reflect that. And it was preserving the current state. So that's really valuable...

emphases.statement: While advanced state management solutions (e.g., Redux, MobX) exist, developers should master basic state management (e.g., using `setState`) first, and only adopt complex solutions when a clear need arises.
emphases.why: This provides crucial practical guidance for students, preventing them from prematurely adopting overly complex solutions before understanding the foundational principles. This is a common pitfall that can lead to unnecessary complexity in projects.
emphases.evidence: The section 'Other approaches' explicitly lists various state management solutions, immediately followed by a prominent 'WARNING' that is repeated verbally by the lecturer. This demonstrates high emphasis on this practical advice.
emphases.from_transcript_quote: WARNING: Learn the basics well before starting these approaches! Try it with setState first. Write a couple of apps with it first. After you really feel the need, start learning about a state management approach.
emphases.from_slide_quote: WARNING: Learn the basics well before starting these approaches! Try it with setState first. Write a couple of apps with it first. After you really feel the need, start learning about a state management approach.

seed_quiz: Explain the fundamental difference between imperative and declarative programming paradigms, providing an example of each in the context of UI development.
What is the 'source of information' problem in traditional UI development, and how does declarative UI attempt to solve it?
Describe how modern declarative UI frameworks (e.g., Flutter, React Native) handle UI updates when data changes, specifically addressing the perceived inefficiency of 're-creating' UI elements.
Differentiate between 'props' (or constructor arguments) and 'state' in a declarative UI. How do they contribute to unidirectional data flow?
The lecturer emphasizes 'developer luxuries' in Flutter. Name two such luxuries and explain how they improve the mobile development experience.
What is the key warning given by the lecturer regarding the adoption of advanced state management solutions?

alignment.summary_chatty: The lecturer provides a highly engaging and thorough exploration of declarative UI, serving as a foundational concept for mobile application development. The verbal lecture extensively covers the philosophical shift from imperative to declarative programming, using clear analogies (like electronic circuits) and real-world problems (like the 'source of information' issue) to explain the 'why' behind this paradigm. The slides serve as an excellent visual backbone, echoing the key definitions, comparisons, and structural concepts like the UI tree and unidirectional data flow. While the lecture elaborates on personal experiences and developer luxuries (like Flutter's hot reload) that aren't fully detailed on the slides, the core technical content—imperative vs. declarative distinctions, how frameworks handle UI re-creation, and the principles of state and props—is well-aligned across both formats. The instructor also provides crucial practical advice and warnings, such as against premature optimization or adopting advanced state management without solid basics, making the content valuable for both conceptual understanding and practical application.

lecture_quotes: Another luxury was I edited some code, saved it and immediately like less than a second usually later I saw it, I saw my running app change to reflect that. And it was preserving the current state.
The two luxuries that I just talked about, tap on something, change code, you need to see it.
slide_refs: So I just made an introduction and reminder about what we did the last two weeks.

segments.text: vSE 380 – Mobile Application Development Lecture 2: Declarative UI Lecturer: Gazihan Alankuş All rights reserved, cannot be used in any educational institution other than Izmir University of Economics. Please look at the couple of slides for assignments (marked with TODO) A problem: source of information Declarative Programming • In • Flutter • React/React Native • Jetpack Compose (Android) • Swift UI (iOS) we create the user interface in a style called “declarative programming”. • The kind of programming that most of you are used to is called “imperative programming”. • Android SDK • iOS SDK • What is the difference? What exactly are they? A computer program vs. an electronic circuit Imperative vs. Declarative Imperative Declarative • Giving orders in detail, with explicit instructions • Describing how it should be • Do this, then do that, then do this other thing. • Programmer has full control. • Programmer has full responsibility. • The computer is dumb. • Here is how I would like it to look like. I don’t have control over how exactly you are doing it. • Programmer has limited control. • Programmer has limited responsibility. • The computer is smart. Imperative vs. Declarative Imperative Declarative • Java • C++ • Step-by-step programming • HTML • SQL • Designing a circuit-like system • Procedural languages • Functional languages Is it just the language? • No, it’s the style. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mt7KnvnNGfk How are React Native and Flutter Declarative? • JavaScript and Dart are procedural languages. Shouldn’t it be imperative? • Answer: there are imperative parts of your code. The code that generates the UI is declarative. Declarative code from React Native and Flutter. Declarative code from React Native and Flutter. • Although the language is suitable for imperative code, the framework forces declarative code. • You create and tie UI elements together. • You do not modify or manage existing UI elements. • There is no such code in either: • txtField.text = “new text” • pnlMain.addChild(txtField) • Instead, there is such code: • new Panel(new TextField(“hello”)); UI Code • React Native • JSX • (short for JavaScript XML) • Similar to HTML • The description for the UI. Creates the UI. • Not actual code • Limited customization • No debugging • Flutter • Widget constructors • Named parameters • child for single child • children for multiple • Actual code! • Fully customizable • Fully debuggable UI is a tree • The UI is a tree structure • Creating a tree is easy • Modifying and maintaining a tree is difficult • This is why they chose declarative • We create and re-create UI elements. We do not manage existing elements. • What? How? • How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a button? Imperative Example • How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a button? Panel panel = new Panel(); TextField t = new TextField(); panel.add(t); t.text = “one”; Button b = new Button(); panel.add(b); b.addClickHandler(() { t.text = “two”; }); • THIS IS IMPERATIVE CODE. THIS MAKES SENSE. • This is not how React Native or Flutter do it. Declarative Example • How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a button? String currentValue = “one”; buildUi() { new Panel( new Text(currentValue), new Button( onClick: () { currentValue = “two”; rebuildUi(); } ) ) } • THIS IS DECLARATIVE CODE. THIS IS COUNTER-INTUITIVE • Why does React Native and Flutter use this pattern? Compare them. Panel panel = new Panel(); TextField t = new TextField(); panel.add(t); t.text = “one”; Button b = new Button(); panel.add(b); b.addClickHandler(() { String currentValue = “one”; buildUi() { new Panel( new Text(currentValue), new Button( onClick: () { currentValue = “two”; rebuildUi(); } ) t.text = “two”; }); ) } The difference • Imperative • Declarative • You create elements • You attach them together • You create elements • You attach them together • You keep a reference to elements • You do not keep a reference to elements • You are not responsible for maintaining elements • You do not give them orders • You create them and forget about them • You are responsible for mainaining them • You give them orders • You recreate them when something changes How can you keep recreating the UI? • Isn’t it inefficient? How can you keep recreating the UI? • Isn’t it inefficient? • NO! People smarter than us have implemented it carefully. • What you are creating is not the real UI element. It’s just a light description of them. • Very light data structure, system is ok with creating and destroying them quickly. • The framework finds the difference between two versions of the tree and modifies the UI elements whose description actually changed. • Carefully crafted framework to give you the ability to “just recreate the UI”. • DO NOT TRY TO OPTIMIZE ANYTHING ABOUT IT!!! • DO NOT CACHE UI ELEMENTS, ETC. KEEP RECREATING THEM. Planning and Creating a Declarative UI • How should you go about planning your UI? • https://reactjs.org/docs/thinking-in-react.html •FilterableProductTable • SearchBar • ProductTable • ProductCategoryRow • ProductRow How does data flow? https://livebook.manning.com/book/react-in-action/chapter-3/112 How does data flow? https://www.slideshare.net/pheadra4/react-46872849?from_action=save How does data flow? https://www.slideshare.net/pheadra4/react-46872849?from_action=save How does data flow? • Unidirectional data flow • Top to bottom • Props/constructor arguments (fixed) • Data being passed down when component is created (yellow). • State (changing) • Temporary data that changes with user input or other events • Triggers a rebuild of subtree. Data is passed down as new version of props. • Bottom to top • Events • Lower level component communicates up https://tkssharma.gitbook.io/react-training/day-01/react-js-3-principles/one-way-data-flow How does data flow? • Unidirectional data flow • Top to bottom • Props/constructor arguments (fixed) • Data being passed down when component is created (yellow). • State (changing) • Temporary data that changes with user input or other events • Triggers a rebuild of subtree. Data is passed down as new version of props. • Bottom to top • Events • Lower level component communicates up https://tkssharma.gitbook.io/react-training/day-01/react-js-3-principles/one-way-data-flow Other approaches • Passing data around can be cumbersome • All intermediate levels need to know about the data being passed to a leaf • Solution: state management • Redux • MobX • Provider • Etc. • WARNING: Learn the basics well before starting these approaches! • Try it with setState first. Write a couple of apps with it first. After you really feel the need, start learning about a state management approach. modules.loTitle: will be able to analyse the requirements of mobile applications
modules.oneLineGist: This LO was not covered in the specific lecture content provided. The lecture focused on UI design and development paradigms, not general mobile application requirements analysis.

modules.loTitle: will be able to design user interfaces and interactions for mobile applications
modules.oneLineGist: Learn the core principles of declarative UI design for mobile apps, contrasting it with imperative approaches and understanding data flow and state management.
coreIdeas: **Imperative vs. Declarative Programming**: Imperative gives detailed step-by-step instructions (e.g., Java, C++), while Declarative describes the desired outcome (e.g., HTML, SQL) and the system figures out how to achieve it.
**UI as a Tree Structure**: User interfaces are inherently hierarchical. While creating a UI tree is easy, modifying and maintaining it imperatively is complex and error-prone.

**Declarative UI Frameworks (Flutter, React Native)**: These frameworks (despite using procedural languages like Dart/JavaScript) force a declarative style. Instead of modifying existing UI elements, you describe and re-create the UI elements based on the current state.

**Efficiency of UI Re-creation**: Declarative frameworks efficiently re-create UI descriptions (light data structures) and then intelligently compare these descriptions to only update the actual UI elements that have changed, making it performant.
**Unidirectional Data Flow (Top-to-Bottom)**: Data flows from parent components to child components via two main mechanisms:
- **Props/Constructor Arguments**: Fixed data passed down when a component is created, used for configuring static aspects.
- **State**: Temporary, changing data internal to a component that triggers a rebuild of its subtree when updated.
**Bottom-to-Top Communication (Events)**: Lower-level components communicate changes or user interactions back up to parent components using events or callbacks.

**State Management Solutions**: For complex applications, direct prop-drilling can be cumbersome. Libraries like Redux, MobX, or Provider offer centralized state management solutions to simplify data sharing across distant components.
mustRemember: **In declarative UIs, you re-create UI descriptions, not modify existing elements directly.**
**'Props' are for fixed, parent-to-child data; 'State' is for changing, internal component data.**
**Declarative frameworks optimize UI updates; do NOT try to manually optimize by caching elements.**
**Unidirectional data flow ensures predictable UI behavior and easier debugging.**
modules.intuitiveExplanation: Imagine you're ordering a custom cake. Imperative is like giving the baker step-by-step instructions: 'First, mix flour and eggs, then bake for 30 minutes, then apply frosting.' You're in full control but also fully responsible. Declarative is like giving the baker a picture and saying, 'I want a cake that looks exactly like this, with 'Happy Birthday' written on it.' You describe the end result, and the smart baker (the framework) figures out the most efficient way to make it, even if you change your mind about the writing later. For UIs, this means you just tell the system what you want to see, and it redraws or updates the necessary parts efficiently, rather than you trying to find and tweak individual UI components.

examples.label: Imperative UI Code
examples.description: To change text in an imperative system: `TextField t = new TextField(); t.text = "one"; ... b.addClickHandler(() { t.text = "two"; });` (Directly modifying an existing UI object's property).

examples.label: Declarative UI Code
examples.description: To change text in a declarative system: `String currentValue = "one"; buildUi() { new Panel( new Text(currentValue), ... Button(onClick: () { currentValue = "two"; rebuildUi(); }) ); }` (Updating a variable and then triggering a re-render of the UI description).

examples.label: UI Planning/Decomposition
examples.description: Breaking down a complex UI like a 'FilterableProductTable' into smaller, reusable components: 'SearchBar', 'ProductTable', 'ProductCategoryRow', 'ProductRow'. Each component describes its own part of the UI based on its props and state.

typicalQuestions: Explain the fundamental difference between imperative and declarative programming paradigms, specifically in the context of UI development for mobile applications.
Describe how modern mobile UI frameworks like Flutter or React Native achieve declarative UI, even when using procedural languages like Dart or JavaScript.
How is data flow typically managed in a declarative UI? Differentiate between 'props' (or constructor arguments) and 'state' as sources of UI data.
You are tasked with designing a component that displays a user's profile picture and name. When would you use 'props' and when might you use 'state' for this component's data?
Why is it generally advised to 'not optimize' UI re-creation in declarative frameworks, and what mechanism makes this possible?
commonTraps: **Confusing UI element instances with their descriptions**: Thinking you're modifying a 'real' UI element directly in declarative code, rather than creating a new description.
**Trying to cache UI elements**: Attempting to reuse UI objects directly, which goes against the declarative philosophy and the framework's optimization strategy.
**Misunderstanding 'State' vs. 'Props'**: Using state for data that should be passed as props, or vice-versa, leading to inefficient updates or incorrect data flow.
**Assuming declarative re-creation is always slow**: Not trusting the framework's underlying optimization (virtual DOM/widget tree diffing) and attempting premature manual optimizations.
**Ignoring unidirectional data flow**: Trying to modify parent component data directly from a child component without using events/callbacks, leading to unpredictable behavior.

miniQuiz.question: What is the primary characteristic of imperative programming?
miniQuiz.answer: Giving explicit, detailed, step-by-step instructions on 'how' to achieve a result.
miniQuiz.why: This defines the core of imperative programming as discussed in the lecture.

miniQuiz.question: In declarative UI, do you modify existing UI elements or re-create their descriptions?
miniQuiz.answer: You re-create their descriptions (lightweight data structures).
miniQuiz.why: This is a fundamental concept of how declarative UI frameworks manage updates and state changes.

miniQuiz.question: What triggers a 'rebuild of subtree' in a declarative UI when data changes?
miniQuiz.why: State is the mechanism for internal, changing data that causes a component and its children to re-render.

miniQuiz.question: If a UI element's description needs to change, why is it not inefficient to recreate the entire description?
miniQuiz.answer: The framework creates lightweight descriptions, finds the differences (diffing algorithm), and only updates the actual UI elements that truly changed, making it efficient.
miniQuiz.why: This explains the optimization mechanism discussed by the lecturer, countering the common misconception of inefficiency.

[1080.00 - 1085.00] Well, just keep it as p at this point in the formula

[1087.00 - 1089.00] That is what we get.
[1089.00 - 1094.00] As you see, the page fault part of the formula
[1094.00 - 1099.00] is the dominating part of the computation.
[1099.00 - 1107.34] Okay, if page fault rate p is 1 over 1000,
[1107.34 - 1115.72] then this turns out to be page point 2 microseconds.
[1115.72 - 1120.72] That is slowed down by a factor of more than 40
[1120.72 - 1123.72] because we have 200 nanoseconds.
[1123.72 - 1125.72] That's terrible.
[1125.72 - 1130.72] So, how can we improve this?
[1130.72 - 1135.72] The only way up is to reduce p.
[1135.72 - 1143.97] So, you say, okay, I want to compute the whole thing backwards.
[1143.97 - 1150.97] I don't want a slow down more than 10 percent.
[1150.97 - 1157.97] So, if that is the picture,
[1157.97 - 1167.97] then you plug it to formula the figures with p ket
[1167.97 - 1175.97] and your effective access time should not be more than 220,
[1175.97 - 1178.97] which is 10 percent.
[1178.97 - 1181.97] Be careful with the apples and oranges.
[1181.97 - 1186.97] This is in nanoseconds, written in nanoseconds.
[1186.97 - 1191.97] So, for p, look at your probability.
[1191.97 - 1201.97] That is one page fault in every 400,000 references.
[1201.97 - 1205.97] So, now comes the big question.
[1205.97 - 1215.97] How am I going to attain a page fault rate of this low?
[1215.97 - 1217.97] Very small.
[1217.97 - 1219.97] The answer is easy.
[1219.97 - 1221.97] Use largely memory.
[1221.97 - 1225.97] Accommodate more pages in memory.
[1225.97 - 1229.97] Well, of course, we have improvements with cache.
[1229.97 - 1231.97] You all know that.
[1231.97 - 1236.97] We use cache to improve memory access time.
[1236.97 - 1241.97] Remember, this included cache references to the page table.
[1241.97 - 1244.97] Remember, when you have page table,

[1247.97 - 1249.97] One memory for the page table
[1249.97 - 1255.97] and then another memory for the actual data.
[1255.97 - 1258.97] So, that is in here.
[1258.97 - 1265.97] So, you can improve things quite a lot by using cache.
[1265.97 - 1268.97] So, that should be the way to go.
[1268.97 - 1272.97] And we do have L1, L2, and L3 caches.
[1272.97 - 1277.97] Now, optimizations, what people did about this?
[1277.97 - 1281.97] Well, they strived for this quite a lot.
[1281.97 - 1288.97] Okay, first of all, speed up the swap operations.
[1288.97 - 1293.97] So, page in page out faster than regular I.O.
[1293.97 - 1296.97] As I said, that would just bring us to the issue

slideText:
SE 380 – Mobile Application
Development
Lecture 2: Declarative UI
Lecturer: Gazihan Alankuş
All rights reserved, cannot be used in any educational institution other than Izmir University
of Economics.

Please look at the couple of slides for assignments (marked with TODO)

 A problem: source of information

  Declarative Programming
• In

• Flutter
• React/React Native
• Jetpack Compose (Android)
• Swift UI (iOS)
we create the user interface in a style called “declarative programming”.

• The kind of programming that most of you are used to is called “imperative
programming”.
• Android SDK
• iOS SDK

• What is the difference? What exactly are they?

 A computer program vs. an electronic circuit

 Imperative vs. Declarative
Imperative

Declarative

• Giving orders in detail, with
explicit instructions

• Describing how it should be

• Do this, then do that, then do this
other thing.

• Programmer has full control.
• Programmer has full responsibility.
• The computer is dumb.

• Here is how I would like it to look
like. I don’t have control over how
exactly you are doing it.

• Programmer has limited control.
• Programmer has limited
responsibility.
• The computer is smart.

 Imperative vs. Declarative
Imperative

Declarative

• Java
• C++
• Step-by-step programming

• HTML
• SQL
• Designing a circuit-like system

• Procedural languages

• Functional languages

 Is it just the language?
• No, it’s the style.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mt7KnvnNGfk

 How are React Native and Flutter Declarative?
• JavaScript and Dart are procedural languages. Shouldn’t it be imperative?
• Answer: there are imperative parts of your code. The code that generates
the UI is declarative.

 Declarative code from React Native and Flutter.

 Declarative code from React Native and Flutter.
• Although the language is suitable for imperative code, the framework
forces declarative code.
• You create and tie UI elements together.
• You do not modify or manage existing UI elements.
• There is no such code in either:
• txtField.text = “new text”
• pnlMain.addChild(txtField)

• Instead, there is such code:
• new Panel(new TextField(“hello”));

 UI Code
• React Native
• JSX
• (short for JavaScript XML)

• Similar to HTML
• The description for the UI. Creates
the UI.
• Not actual code
• Limited customization
• No debugging

• Flutter
• Widget constructors
• Named parameters
• child for single child
• children for multiple

• Actual code!
• Fully customizable
• Fully debuggable

 UI is a tree
• The UI is a tree structure
• Creating a tree is easy
• Modifying and maintaining a tree is difficult

• This is why they chose declarative

• We create and re-create UI elements. We do not manage existing
elements.
• What? How?
• How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a
button?

 Imperative Example
• How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press
a button?
Panel panel = new Panel();
TextField t = new TextField();
panel.add(t);
t.text = “one”;
Button b = new Button();
panel.add(b);
b.addClickHandler(() {
t.text = “two”;

});
• THIS IS IMPERATIVE CODE. THIS MAKES SENSE.
• This is not how React Native or Flutter do it.

 Declarative Example
• How do you make a text field say “one” first, and then say “two” after you press a
button?
String currentValue = “one”;
buildUi() {
new Panel(
new Text(currentValue),
new Button(
onClick: () {
currentValue = “two”;
rebuildUi();
}
)

)

}

• THIS IS DECLARATIVE CODE. THIS IS COUNTER-INTUITIVE
• Why does React Native and Flutter use this pattern?

 Compare them.
Panel panel = new Panel();
TextField t = new TextField();
panel.add(t);
t.text = “one”;
Button b = new Button();
panel.add(b);
b.addClickHandler(() {

String currentValue = “one”;
buildUi() {
new Panel(
new Text(currentValue),
new Button(
onClick: () {
currentValue = “two”;
rebuildUi();
}
)

t.text = “two”;

});

)

}

 The difference
• Imperative

• Declarative

• You create elements
• You attach them together

• You create elements
• You attach them together

• You keep a reference to elements

• You do not keep a reference to elements
• You are not responsible for maintaining
elements
• You do not give them orders
• You create them and forget about them

• You are responsible for mainaining them
• You give them orders

• You recreate them when something
changes

 How can you keep recreating the UI?
• Isn’t it inefficient?

 How can you keep recreating the UI?
• Isn’t it inefficient?
• NO! People smarter than us have implemented it carefully.
• What you are creating is not the real UI element. It’s just a light description of them.
• Very light data structure, system is ok with creating and destroying them quickly.

• The framework finds the difference between two versions of the tree and modifies the UI
elements whose description actually changed.
• Carefully crafted framework to give you the ability to “just recreate the UI”.

• DO NOT TRY TO OPTIMIZE ANYTHING ABOUT IT!!!
• DO NOT CACHE UI ELEMENTS, ETC. KEEP RECREATING THEM.

 Planning and Creating a Declarative UI
• How should you go about planning your UI?
• https://reactjs.org/docs/thinking-in-react.html
•FilterableProductTable
• SearchBar
• ProductTable
• ProductCategoryRow
• ProductRow

 How does data flow?

https://livebook.manning.com/book/react-in-action/chapter-3/112

 How does data flow?

https://www.slideshare.net/pheadra4/react-46872849?from_action=save

 How does data flow?

https://www.slideshare.net/pheadra4/react-46872849?from_action=save

 How does data flow?
• Unidirectional data flow
• Top to bottom
• Props/constructor arguments (fixed)
• Data being passed down when
component is created (yellow).

• State (changing)
• Temporary data that changes with user
input or other events
• Triggers a rebuild of subtree. Data is
passed down as new version of props.

• Bottom to top
• Events
• Lower level component communicates up

https://tkssharma.gitbook.io/react-training/day-01/react-js-3-principles/one-way-data-flow

 How does data flow?
• Unidirectional data flow
• Top to bottom
• Props/constructor arguments (fixed)
• Data being passed down when
component is created (yellow).

• State (changing)
• Temporary data that changes with user
input or other events
• Triggers a rebuild of subtree. Data is
passed down as new version of props.

• Bottom to top
• Events
• Lower level component communicates up

https://tkssharma.gitbook.io/react-training/day-01/react-js-3-principles/one-way-data-flow

 Other approaches
• Passing data around can be cumbersome
• All intermediate levels need to know about the data being passed to a leaf
• Solution: state management
• Redux
• MobX
• Provider
• Etc.

• WARNING: Learn the basics well before starting these approaches!
• Try it with setState first. Write a couple of apps with it first. After you really feel the
need, start learning about a state management approach.

professorEmphases.statement: The process of handling a page fault is a critical, multi-step sequence involving the OS, disk operations, and scheduler, which must be thoroughly understood.
professorEmphases.why: This process is a fundamental concept in virtual memory management. Understanding each step is crucial for comprehending system behavior under memory pressure and for identifying performance bottlenecks. It is likely an examinable, detailed process.
professorEmphases.evidence: The lecturer spends significant time detailing the 'story of page fault', repeating and reinforcing the steps involved, and explicitly stating, 'That needs to be understood very well.'
professorEmphases.from_transcript_quote: And when you check the page table, unfortunately the page is not in memory. That's a trap to the operating system. [...] So, this is the story of page 4. That needs to be understood very well.

professorEmphases.statement: Page faults severely degrade system performance due to slow disk access, and the page fault rate (P) is the dominant factor in calculating effective memory access time.
professorEmphases.why: This highlights the practical implications of paging and provides a quantitative measure (Effective Access Time) for evaluating performance. Understanding the formula and the significance of 'P' is key for analyzing and optimizing virtual memory systems, making it highly relevant for problem-solving and exams.
professorEmphases.evidence: The lecturer dedicates a substantial segment to performance, introduces the page fault rate 'P', provides a formula, performs a numerical example, and explicitly states, 'the page fault part of the formula is the dominating part of the computation.'
professorEmphases.from_transcript_quote: We say, well, we do have worries about performance. Why? Because I am setting up disk operations and disk operations take a long time. [...] As you see, the page fault part of the formula is the dominating part of the computation.

professorEmphases.statement: The Memory Management Unit (MMU) is essential for controlling memory traffic, and its operations are transparent to the user program.
professorEmphases.why: This establishes the fundamental role of the MMU and its user-facing characteristic. Transparency is a key design principle in OS, and understanding the MMU's role is foundational for grasping how virtual memory works without programmer intervention.
professorEmphases.evidence: The lecturer defines the MMU's role early on and explicitly states the transparency aspect, which is a core feature of memory management.
professorEmphases.from_transcript_quote: So, the basic functionality of memory management unit is to control this traffic. [...] No, the activities of memory manager are transparent to the user.

professorEmphases.statement: Locality of reference is a very important phenomenon that explains why paging systems are effective, as programs tend to access a limited set of pages in specific time windows.
professorEmphases.why: This concept underpins the effectiveness of virtual memory and caching. Understanding locality helps explain why systems can perform well even with limited physical memory and informs design choices for memory management algorithms. It's a key conceptual foundation.
professorEmphases.evidence: The lecturer introduces 'locality of reference' as a 'very important phenomenon' and explains its meaning, emphasizing its role in program execution efficiency.
professorEmphases.from_transcript_quote: Now at this point, it's a good idea to talk about a very important phenomenon called locality of reference. [...] the program needs only certain pages for execution.

professorEmphases.statement: Improving paging performance primarily involves reducing the page fault rate (P) through various optimizations, such as using larger memory, prioritizing swap operations, and leveraging caches.
professorEmphases.why: This addresses the practical challenge of managing performance in a paging system. Students need to know not just the problem but also the solutions and design considerations for efficient memory management.
professorEmphases.evidence: After discussing performance degradation, the lecturer explicitly asks 'How can we improve this?' and lists 'reduce p', 'use largely memory', 'speed up the swap operations', and 'use cache' as solutions.
professorEmphases.from_transcript_quote: So, how can we improve this? The only way up is to reduce p. [...] We use cache to improve memory access time. [...] speed up the swap operations.

plan.topic: Declarative UI in Mobile Application Development

modules.title: Module 1: Understanding Declarative vs. Imperative UI
modules.goal: Differentiate between imperative and declarative programming paradigms, specifically in the context of UI development for mobile applications.

lessons.title: Lesson 1.1: Introduction to UI Paradigms
lessons.objective: Define imperative and declarative programming and list common examples of each.

activities.prompt: Review slides on 'Declarative Programming' and 'Imperative vs. Declarative' (Slides 4-7) to understand core definitions and comparisons.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can define both paradigms and identify their characteristics.

activities.prompt: If available, watch a conceptual video explaining the fundamental differences between imperative and declarative programming.
activities.expected_outcome: Students gain a deeper intuitive understanding of the two paradigms.

activities.prompt: Given various pseudo-code snippets or descriptions of tasks, categorize them as primarily imperative or declarative. E.g., 'Write a recipe step-by-step' vs. 'Describe the final dish'.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can correctly identify the paradigm of a given task or code structure.

mini_quiz: What is the primary difference in *how instructions are given* between imperative and declarative programming?
Name one example language or technology for imperative programming and one for declarative programming as mentioned in the slides.

lessons.title: Lesson 1.2: Declarative UI in Mobile Frameworks
lessons.objective: Explain how frameworks like Flutter and React Native utilize a declarative style despite underlying procedural languages, focusing on UI generation.

activities.prompt: Examine slides 'How are React Native and Flutter Declarative?' and 'Declarative code from React Native and Flutter' (Slides 9-11) to understand framework-specific implementations.
activities.expected_outcome: Students grasp how declarative principles are applied in modern mobile UI frameworks.

activities.prompt: Search for a short demonstration video showing basic UI component creation in Flutter or React Native.
activities.expected_outcome: Students visualize the declarative UI code structure in practice.

activities.prompt: Analyze example UI code snippets (e.g., `txtField.text = 'new text'` vs. `new Panel(new TextField('hello'))`) and explain why one is imperative and the other declarative in the context of UI modification.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can articulate the difference between direct UI manipulation and declarative UI construction.

mini_quiz: Why do JavaScript/Dart, which are typically procedural languages, allow for declarative UI development in Flutter/React Native?
Give an example of an *imperative* UI modification that is generally *avoided* in declarative frameworks like Flutter or React Native.

modules.title: Module 2: Building Declarative UIs
modules.goal: Understand the underlying mechanism and best practices for constructing UIs using a declarative approach, including component structuring and reconciliation.

lessons.title: Lesson 2.1: UI as a Tree and Reconciliation
lessons.objective: Describe why UI elements are represented as a tree structure and explain the mechanism of recreating and reconciling UI elements in declarative frameworks.

activities.prompt: Study slides 'UI is a tree' and 'How can you keep recreating the UI?' (Slides 13-14) to understand the conceptual model and performance implications.
activities.expected_outcome: Students understand the UI tree concept and the framework's role in efficient updates.

activities.prompt: Look for an animation or explanation of 'Virtual DOM' or 'Widget Tree diffing' to visualize how frameworks efficiently update the UI.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can conceptually explain how declarative UI frameworks achieve performance by comparing UI descriptions.

activities.prompt: Explain why directly modifying UI elements (`t.text = "two"`) is discouraged in declarative frameworks and what the alternative pattern is (`rebuildUi()`).
activities.expected_outcome: Students can justify the declarative approach of UI recreation over direct manipulation.

mini_quiz: What is the main structural representation used for UIs in declarative frameworks?
Why is constantly 'recreating' UI elements in declarative frameworks not as inefficient as it might initially seem?

lessons.title: Lesson 2.2: Planning and Conceptualizing Declarative UI
lessons.objective: Apply a structured approach to decompose a UI design into declarative components, following best practices for component-based architecture.

activities.prompt: Review slides on 'Planning and Creating a Declarative UI' and 'How does data flow?' (Slides 15-18). Pay special attention to the 'Thinking in React' example.
activities.expected_outcome: Students understand how to break down a complex UI into manageable, reusable components.

activities.prompt: Take a simple UI design (e.g., an e-commerce product detail screen) and, similar to the 'FilterableProductTable' example, break it down into a hierarchy of logical components. Identify potential props and state for each.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can independently identify and structure components for a given UI design.

activities.prompt: Given a diagram of a UI, identify and name at least five distinct components you would create using a declarative approach.
activities.expected_outcome: Students demonstrate the ability to componentize a UI effectively.

mini_quiz: List the typical components one might identify when planning a 'FilterableProductTable' in a declarative UI, based on the provided example.
Why is it important to think of your UI in terms of components and a hierarchy?

modules.title: Module 3: Data Management in Declarative UI
modules.goal: Understand how data flows and is managed within a declarative UI architecture, differentiating between props, state, and events, and recognizing the role of advanced state management.

lessons.title: Lesson 3.1: Unidirectional Data Flow (Props & State)
lessons.objective: Explain the concepts of props, state, and events in the context of unidirectional data flow in declarative UIs.

activities.prompt: Carefully read slides on 'How does data flow?' (Slides 19-21), focusing on the definitions and roles of 'Props/constructor arguments', 'State', and 'Events'.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can define and differentiate between props, state, and events in declarative UI.

activities.prompt: Given a simple declarative UI example with parent and child components, trace the flow of data (identifying what would be passed as props versus what would be managed as state) and how a user action in a child component might trigger an event.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can accurately apply the concepts of props, state, and events to a practical scenario.

mini_quiz: What is the primary difference between `props` (or constructor arguments) and `state` in declarative UI components regarding their mutability and source?
How do lower-level components typically communicate changes or user interactions *up* the component hierarchy in a unidirectional data flow architecture?

lessons.title: Lesson 3.2: Advanced State Management
lessons.objective: Identify scenarios where advanced state management solutions might be beneficial and understand the instructor's caution regarding their adoption.

activities.prompt: Review slide 'Other approaches' (Slide 22). Conduct a brief online search (5-10 minutes) for 'Redux' or 'Provider' to get a high-level understanding of what problems they aim to solve.
activities.expected_outcome: Students can name common state management solutions and understand the motivation behind them.

activities.prompt: Consider a complex application with many nested components and shared data. Imagine how passing data using only props and state might become cumbersome ('prop drilling'). How might an advanced state management solution help?
activities.expected_outcome: Students can articulate the challenges of basic data flow in large applications and the potential benefits of state management.

mini_quiz: Name two advanced state management solutions mentioned in the slides.
What critical advice does the instructor give regarding when to adopt advanced state management solutions in declarative UI development?

alignment.summary_chatty: It appears there's a significant mismatch between the lecture transcript and the provided slides for this session. The lecture focuses almost exclusively on Operating Systems concepts like virtual memory, paging, page faults, and memory management unit (MMU), even referencing 'last week's lecture' on these topics. In stark contrast, the slides are clearly titled for a 'Mobile Application Development' course and delve into 'Declarative UI' using frameworks like Flutter and React Native. Consequently, there is virtually no conceptual overlap between what the teacher *said* in the transcript and what the *slides presented*. Key concepts from the lecture (e.g., page fault handling, effective access time) are entirely absent from the slides, and vice-versa for the slides' content (e.g., declarative vs. imperative UI, unidirectional data flow).

transcript:
[00:00:00 – 00:00:15] Good morning everyone and welcome to today's lecture on Python functions. I'm really excited to dive into this topic because functions are absolutely fundamental to programming.

[00:00:15 – 00:00:28] They're one of the most important concepts you'll learn. So let's start with the basics. What exactly is a function?

[00:00:28 – 00:00:45] Well, a function is essentially a reusable block of code that performs a specific task. Think of it like a machine - you put something in, it does some work, and it gives you something back.

[00:00:45 – 00:01:02] The beauty of functions is that once you write them, you can use them over and over again without rewriting the same code.

[00:01:02 – 00:01:18] Now, why should we use functions? There are several compelling reasons. First, code reusability. Instead of copying and pasting the same code everywhere, you write it once as a function and call it whenever you need it.

[00:01:18 – 00:01:35] Second, organization. Functions help you break down complex programs into smaller, manageable pieces. Third, maintainability. When you need to fix a bug or make a change, you only need to update it in one place.

[00:01:35 – 00:01:52] Let me show you how to define a function. We use the 'def' keyword, followed by the function name, then parentheses, and a colon. The function body is indented.

[00:01:52 – 00:02:08] For example, def greet colon, then on the next line, indented, print hello. That's it. That's a simple function.

[00:02:08 – 00:02:25] Now let's talk about parameters and arguments. These terms are often confused but there's an important distinction. Parameters are the variables you define in the function definition.

[00:02:25 – 00:02:42] Arguments are the actual values you pass when you call the function. So if I have def add open parenthesis a comma b close parenthesis, a and b are parameters. When I call add 5 comma 3, 5 and 3 are arguments.

[00:02:42 – 00:03:00] There are different types of arguments. Positional arguments where the order matters. Keyword arguments where you specify the parameter name. And default parameters that have fallback values if nothing is provided.

[00:03:00 – 00:03:18] Finally, let's discuss the return statement. When you want a function to give back a result, you use return. For example, def add a b colon return a plus b. The function computes the sum and returns it.

[00:03:18 – 00:03:35] If you don't use return, the function returns None by default. Also, return immediately exits the function, so any code after return won't execute.

[00:03:35 – 00:03:52] Remember, good functions are small and focused. One function should do one thing and do it well. Use descriptive names so others can understand what your function does just by reading the name.

[00:03:52 – 00:04:05] And always document your functions with docstrings. Any questions so far? Great, let's move on to some practice exercises.
slideText:
Introduction to Python Functions

What is a Function?
- A block of code which only runs when it is called.
- You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.
- A function can return data as a result.
- Functions help organize code and make it reusable.

Why Use Functions?
- Code Reusability: Write once, use many times
- Organization: Break complex programs into smaller pieces
- Maintainability: Easier to debug and update
- Abstraction: Hide implementation details

Defining a Function
- Use the 'def' keyword to define a function
- Function name should be descriptive and use snake_case
- Parameters are placed inside parentheses
- Function body is indented with 4 spaces
- Example: def greet(name):

Parameters vs Arguments
- Parameters: Variables in the function definition
- Arguments: Actual values passed when calling
- Positional arguments: Order matters
- Keyword arguments: Specify by name
- Default parameters: Provide fallback values

The Return Statement
- Use 'return' to send a value back from the function
- A function can return multiple values as a tuple
- If no return statement, function returns None
- Return immediately exits the function
- Example: return x + y

Best Practices
- Keep functions small and focused
- One function should do one thing
- Use descriptive names
- Document with docstrings
- Avoid global variables inside functions

modules.title: Module 1: Fundamentals of Python Functions
modules.goal: Understand the core concepts of Python functions, including their purpose, definition, and basic usage, to write more organized and efficient code.

lessons.title: Introduction: What are Functions and Why Use Them?
lessons.objective: Define what a Python function is and articulate the key benefits of using functions in programming, such as reusability, organization, and maintainability.

activities.prompt: Review the lecture segment on 'What is a Function?' and 'Why Use Functions?'.
activities.expected_outcome: Identify the core definition and at least three reasons for using functions.

activities.prompt: Read the 'Introduction to Python Functions' and 'Why Use Functions?' sections of a Python tutorial (e.g., W3Schools Python Functions).
activities.expected_outcome: Reinforce understanding of function purpose and benefits.

activities.prompt: Think of a simple, repetitive task you might perform in a program (e.g., printing a greeting). Brainstorm how a function could make this task more efficient.
activities.expected_outcome: Formulate a hypothetical scenario demonstrating code reusability.

mini_quiz: What is the primary benefit of 'code reusability' when using functions?
How do functions contribute to better program 'organization'?
If you find a bug in a function, why is it easier to fix than if you had copied the code multiple times?

lessons.title: Defining Functions and Basic Syntax
lessons.objective: Correctly define a simple Python function using the 'def' keyword, understand indentation, and distinguish between function definition and function call.

activities.prompt: Review the lecture segment on 'Defining a Function' and the example `def greet: print hello`.
activities.expected_outcome: Identify the 'def' keyword, colon, and indentation as crucial syntax elements.

activities.prompt: Consult a Python documentation or tutorial section on basic function definition syntax.
activities.expected_outcome: Understand the formal rules for naming functions and code indentation.

activities.prompt: Write a simple Python function named `say_hello` that prints 'Hello, Python!' when called. Then, call the function.
activities.expected_outcome: Successfully define and execute a basic function.

mini_quiz: Which keyword is used to define a function in Python?
What is the significance of indentation in a function's body?
Write the first line of a function definition for a function named `calculate_area` that takes no inputs.

lessons.title: Parameters, Arguments, and Return Values
lessons.objective: Differentiate between parameters and arguments, utilize various argument types (positional, keyword, default), and implement the `return` statement to send values from functions.

activities.prompt: Review the lecture segment on 'Parameters vs Arguments' and 'The Return Statement'. Pay close attention to the `add(a, b)` example.
activities.expected_outcome: Clearly understand the distinction between parameters (definition) and arguments (call), and how `return` works.

activities.prompt: Read detailed explanations of positional, keyword, and default arguments, as well as the `return` statement's behavior (including `None` and immediate exit).
activities.expected_outcome: Grasp the flexibility and implications of different argument passing methods and return values.

activities.prompt: Write a function `multiply(x, y)` that returns the product of `x` and `y`. Call it using both positional and keyword arguments. Then, write a function `get_info(name, age=30)` that prints the name and age, demonstrating a default parameter.
activities.expected_outcome: Implement functions with parameters and arguments, including default values, and correctly use the `return` statement.

mini_quiz: In `def func(p1, p2):`, what are `p1` and `p2` called?
If you call `func(arg1, arg2)`, what are `arg1` and `arg2` called?
What value does a function return if there is no explicit `return` statement?
What happens to code placed immediately after a `return` statement within a function?

lessons.title: Function Best Practices
lessons.objective: Apply best practices for writing clean, readable, and maintainable functions, including principles like single responsibility, descriptive naming, and documentation.

activities.prompt: Review the lecture segment on 'Best Practices' for functions.
activities.expected_outcome: Identify at least three key principles for writing good functions.

activities.prompt: Read a style guide (e.g., PEP 8 for Python) section on function naming, docstrings, and function length/focus.
activities.expected_outcome: Understand industry standards for function quality.

activities.prompt: Refactor a previously written function (e.g., `multiply`) to ensure it has a descriptive name, a docstring, and performs only one task.
activities.expected_outcome: Improve a function's readability and adherence to best practices.

mini_quiz: What is the 'single responsibility principle' in the context of functions?
Why is it important to use 'descriptive names' for functions?
What are 'docstrings' used for in Python functions?

segments.text: Second, organization. Functions help you break down complex programs into smaller, manageable pieces. Third, maintainability. When you need to fix a bug or make a change, you only need to update it in one place.
segments.reason: Medium slide match (sim=0.44) → likely elaboration

segments.text: Let me show you how to define a function. We use the 'def' keyword, followed by the function name, then parentheses, and a colon. The function body is indented.
segments.reason: High slide match (sim=0.65)

segments.text: For example, def greet colon, then on the next line, indented, print hello. That's it. That's a simple function.
segments.reason: Medium slide match (sim=0.54) → likely elaboration

segments.text: Now let's talk about parameters and arguments. These terms are often confused but there's an important distinction. Parameters are the variables you define in the function definition.
segments.reason: Medium slide match (sim=0.50) → likely elaboration

segments.text: Arguments are the actual values you pass when you call the function. So if I have def add open parenthesis a comma b close parenthesis, a and b are parameters. When I call add 5 comma 3, 5 and 3 are arguments.
segments.reason: Medium slide match (sim=0.54) → likely elaboration

segments.text: There are different types of arguments. Positional arguments where the order matters. Keyword arguments where you specify the parameter name. And default parameters that have fallback values if nothing is provided.

segments.reason: Medium slide match (sim=0.54) → likely elaboration

segments.text: If you don't use return, the function returns None by default. Also, return immediately exits the function, so any code after return won't execute.
segments.reason: Medium slide match (sim=0.36) → likely elaboration

cheatSheet.title: Python Functions: Quick Revision

sections.heading: What are Functions?
bullets: **Fundamental** reusable block of code that performs a specific task.
Only runs when it is called.
Helps organize code and makes it reusable.
Think of it as a 'machine': input → work → output.

sections.heading: Why Use Functions? (Key Benefits)
bullets: **Code Reusability:** Write code once, use it many times.
**Organization:** Break down complex programs into smaller, manageable pieces.
**Maintainability:** Easier to debug and update in one central place.
Abstraction: Hide complex implementation details.

sections.heading: Defining & Calling Functions
bullets: Use `def` keyword, followed by name, parentheses, and colon.
Function body is indented (conventionally 4 spaces).
Example: `def greet(name):`
Call function by its name followed by parentheses: `greet("Alice")`.

sections.heading: Parameters vs. Arguments (Crucial Distinction!)
bullets: **Parameters:** Variables defined in the function definition (e.g., `a, b` in `def add(a, b):`).
**Arguments:** Actual values passed when calling the function (e.g., `5, 3` in `add(5, 3)`).
**Positional arguments:** Order of values matters.
**Keyword arguments:** Specify by parameter name (e.g., `add(b=3, a=5)`).
**Default parameters:** Provide fallback values if not provided by caller (e.g., `def greet(name="Guest"):`).

sections.heading: The `return` Statement
bullets: Used to send a value back as the function's result.
**Immediately exits** the function; any code after `return` is NOT executed.
If no `return` statement, the function implicitly returns `None`.
Can return multiple values, which are packaged as a tuple.

sections.heading: Best Practices for Good Functions
bullets: **Small & Focused:** One function should do one thing, and do it well.
**Descriptive Names:** Use `snake_case` and make names explain purpose (e.g., `calculate_total`).
**Document with Docstrings:** Explain function's purpose, parameters, and return value.
Avoid using global variables inside functions (can lead to side effects).

pitfalls: **Confusing Parameters & Arguments:** Incorrectly using terms or expecting arguments to be defined like parameters.
**Forgetting `return`:** Expecting a function to produce a usable value, but getting `None` because `return` was omitted.
**Code After `return`:** Writing code after a `return` statement and expecting it to execute.
**Overly Complex Functions:** Creating large functions that do too many things, making them hard to test, debug, and reuse.
**Undocumented Functions:** Leaving functions without docstrings or clear names, making them difficult for others (or your future self) to understand.

quickQuiz.q: What is the primary benefit of 'Code Reusability' with functions?
quickQuiz.a: Write code once, use it many times without duplication.

quickQuiz.q: What is the key difference between a 'parameter' and an 'argument'?
quickQuiz.a: Parameter is variable in function definition; argument is actual value passed when called.

quickQuiz.q: What does a Python function return by default if no `return` statement is used?
What happens to code located directly after a `return` statement in a function?
quickQuiz.a: It is not executed; the function immediately exits.

quickQuiz.q: Name two best practices for writing good Python functions.
quickQuiz.a: Keep small and focused; use descriptive names; document with docstrings.

ae, Priority Inheritance Protocol

= Consider the scenario with three processes P1, P2, and P3. P1 has
the highest priority, P2 the next highest, and P3 the lowest.

� Assume P3 is assigned a resource R that P1 wants.

* Thus, P1 must wait for P3 to finish using the resource. However,
P2 becomes runnable and preempts P3.

* Whathas happened is that P2 - a process with a lower priority
than P1 - has indirectly prevented P3 from gaining access to the
resource.

" To prevent this from occurring, a priority inheritance protocol is
used. This simply allows the priority of the highest thread waiting to
access a shared resource to be assigned to the thread currently using
the resource. Thus, the current owner of the resource is assigned the
priority of the highest priority thread wishing to acquire the resource.
